tossups.question: The title of a Beverley Daniel Tatum book asks "Why are all [these people] sitting together in the cafeteria?". Each chapter of a book titled for these people begins with a few bars of "sorrow songs", including "The Coming of John". "Spiritual strivings" title the first chapter of a book about these people; that book uses the term "the Veil" for the places where they are the dominant culture. A book titled for these people says that they can only see themselves "through the revelation of the other world", a concept termed (*) "double consciousness." "Nobody knows the trouble I've seen" and "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot" are examples of spirituals these people wrote. A pioneering work of sociology by W. E. B. DuBois is titled for "the souls" of these people. For 10 points, name these people for whom Booker T. Washington promoted trade education in his book Up From Slavery.
tossups.answer: Black people [accept Black kids or Black folk or African-Americans or Why Are All The Black Kids Sitting Together In The Cafeteria?, The Souls of Black Folk; prompt on slaves by asking "What broader group of people were those slaves a part of?"]

DuBois is titled for "the souls" of these people. For 10 points, name these people for whom Booker T. Washington promoted trade education in his book Up From Slavery.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Black people [accept Black kids or Black folk or African-Americans or Why Are All The Black Kids Sitting Together In The Cafeteria?, The Souls of Black Folk; prompt on slaves by asking "What broader group of people were those slaves a part of?"]

tossups.question: Manjul Bhargava generalized this function to any infinite subset of the integers. Those polynomials derived from this function are symbolized by the Pochhammer (“POKE-hammer”) symbol, and can be “rising” or “falling.” An extension of this function to the complex numbers is defined by the Euler (“oiler”) integral of the second kind, and is undefined for negative integers. That extension of this function is the gamma function. This function of n appears in the denominator of the (*) Taylor series formula. The number of permutations of a set with n non-repeating elements is equal to this function of n. Because this function is defined recursively, it is assigned an initial value of “one” when n equals zero. For 10 points, name this function which, for the number 4, is equal to 4 times 3 times 2 times 1.
tossups.question_sanitized: Manjul Bhargava generalized this function to any infinite subset of the integers. Those polynomials derived from this function are symbolized by the Pochhammer (“POKE-hammer”) symbol, and can be “rising” or “falling.”  An extension of this function to the complex numbers is defined by the Euler (“oiler”) integral of the second kind, and is undefined for negative integers. That extension of this function is the gamma function. This function of n appears in the denominator of the (*) Taylor series formula. The number of permutations of a set with n non-repeating elements is equal to this function of n. Because this function is defined recursively, it is assigned an initial value of “one” when n equals zero. For 10 points, name this function which, for the number 4, is equal to 4 times 3 times 2 times 1.
tossups.answer_sanitized: factorial function [or n factorial; accept gamma function before “gamma”]

tossups.question: This man fought with rival William Hyde in Olive Street after accusing him of being an alcoholic. This man’s reputation was damaged by the killing of former confederate general Alonzo Slayback and he spent the last years of his life on the soundproofed yacht Liberty with his personal doctor C. Louis Leipoldt. This man began his career working for Carl Schurz’s Weltische Post ("VELL-tish-uh POST") in St. Louis where he started the St. Louis Post and Dispatch. Richard Outcault was employed by this man to write The (*) Yellow Kid, one of the first comic strips. This rival of William Randolph Hearst provided a bequest for a school of journalism at Columbia University. For 10 points, name this Hungarian-American publisher of the New York World, the namesake of Journalism’s most prestigious prizes.
tossups.question_sanitized: This man fought with rival William Hyde in Olive Street after accusing him of being an alcoholic. This man’s reputation was damaged by the killing of former confederate general Alonzo Slayback and he spent the last years of his life on the soundproofed yacht Liberty with his personal doctor C. Louis Leipoldt. This man began his career working for Carl Schurz’s Weltische Post ("VELL-tish-uh POST") in St. Louis where he started the St. Louis Post and Dispatch. Richard Outcault was employed by this man to write The (*) Yellow Kid, one of the first comic strips. This rival of William Randolph Hearst provided a bequest for a school of journalism at Columbia University. For 10 points, name this Hungarian-American publisher of the New York World, the namesake of Journalism’s most prestigious prizes.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Joseph Pulitzer [or József Pulitzer]

tossups.question: Japanese sculptor Taku Inoue ("tah-koo ee-NO-way") became famous for humorous clay sculptures of this character distorted into various shapes. This character cameos as a butler in Anchors Aweigh, in which he offers the lonesome king a large cheese platter. In order to woo Toodles Galore, this character played a pizzicato bassline on a double-bass for his rendition of (*) “Is You Is or Is You Ain’t My Baby.” In his first appearance, this character is called Jasper and told “I means out! O-U-W-T, out!” by a racist caricature named Mammy Two Shoes. This character’s rival attempts to frame him by breaking glasses and dishes in the first cartoon directed by Bill Hanna and Joe Barbera ("bar-BEAR-uh"). For 10 points, name this gray cat who chases a brown mouse named Jerry.
tossups.answer: Tom Cat [or Thomas D. Cat; prompt on Tom and Jerry or Cat]

For 10 points, name this gray cat who chases a brown mouse named Jerry.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Tom Cat [or Thomas D. Cat; prompt on Tom and Jerry or Cat]

tossups.question: Phenytoin ("fuh-NIT-o-win"), a drug that treats this condition, may cause Stevens-Johnson syndrome. The Merced ("mer-SED") Community Medical Center diagnoses Lia Lee with a severe form of this condition called Lennox-Gastaut ("LEN-nucks gas-TOE") syndrome in an ethnography by Anne Fadiman. Dostoevsky’s ("doss-ta-YEV-skee’s") experience having this condition informed his portrayal of Prince Myshkin ("MISH-kin") in The Idiot. This condition’s tonic-clonic symptoms used to be described as (*) “grand mal.” Plutarch cited this condition to explain why Julius Caesar did not stand when he was deified, leading Shakespeare to describe this condition as “the falling sickness.” This condition’s most common symptoms often happen as reflexes to sudden noises or rapidly-flashing lights. For 10 points, name this condition characterized by recurring seizures.
tossups.answer: epilepsy [accept seizures or seizure disorders before “seizures”; prompt on falling sickness before “the falling sickness”]

For 10 points, name this condition characterized by recurring seizures.
tossups.answer_sanitized: epilepsy [accept seizures or seizure disorders before “seizures”; prompt on falling sickness before “the falling sickness”]

tossups.question: In 1993, the Niobe Room of this building was damaged in an early-morning car bombing. A busy painting of this building shows the amusingly named Other Winsdor standing beside the artist. Johann Zoffany was hired by King George III to paint this building’s Tribuna. Giorgio Vasari built a corridor that connects this building with the Palazzo (*) Pitti. This museum holds the Venus of Urbino. The name of this museum derives from the fact that it was constructed by Cosimo de’ Medici to house administrative offices. This museum holds major works by Botticlli, such as Primavera and The Birth of Venus. For 10 points, name this major art museum in Florence.
tossups.question_sanitized: In 1993, the Niobe Room of this building was damaged in an early-morning car bombing. A busy painting of this building shows the amusingly named Other Winsdor standing beside the artist. Johann Zoffany was hired by King George III to paint this building’s Tribuna. Giorgio Vasari built a corridor that connects this building with the Palazzo (*) Pitti. This museum holds the Venus of Urbino. The name of this museum derives from the fact that it was constructed by Cosimo de’ Medici to house administrative offices. This museum holds major works by Botticlli, such as Primavera and The Birth of Venus. For 10 points, name this major art museum in Florence.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Uffizi Gallery [or Galleria degli Uffizi]

tossups.question: Letters that this author wrote to Ellen Nussey were the primary source for the first biography of this author. The Lucy poems by Wordsworth and the teacher Constantin Héger inspired major characters in a novel by this author, according to the scholars Gilbert and Gubar. This author was the primary creator of the fictional setting of Glass Town. The first biography of this novelist was written by Elizabeth Gaskell. This author inspired a later writer to create the character Antoinette (*) Cosway. A novel by this author inspired the title of the 1979 book The Madwoman in the Attic, as well as the Jean Rhys novel Wide Sargasso Sea. This author created Bertha Mason, the first wife of Mr Rochester. For 10 points, name this author of Jane Eyre.
tossups.question_sanitized: Letters that this author wrote to Ellen Nussey were the primary source for the first biography of this author. A novel by this author inspired the title of the 1979 book The Madwoman in the Attic, as well as the Jean Rhys novel Wide Sargasso Sea. This author created Bertha Mason, the first wife of Mr Rochester. For 10 points, name this author of Jane Eyre.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Charlotte Brontë [accept Currer Bell]

tossups.question: Nicholas Bouvier’s The Way of the World relates a journey ending at this location. Copious counterfeit arms produced in this area are known as its namesake “copy”. For periods, this area was controlled by Khalil and Afridi tribesmen. A traditional phrase showing the extent of one country spoke of it as stretching from this place to Kanyakumari. Hari Singh Nalwa defended the eastern end of this place at the Battle of Jamrud as the forces of Dost Mohammad Khan sought to recapture the city of (*) Peshawar. The final section of the Durand line to be drawn was that near this area. This pass crosses the Spin Ghar mountains linking Landi Kotal with the Peshawar Valley in the North-west of Pakistan. For 10 points, name this mountain pass often seen as the entry point to the Indian subcontinent.
tossups.question_sanitized: Nicholas Bouvier’s The Way of the World relates a journey ending at this location. Copious counterfeit arms produced in this area are known as its namesake “copy”.  For periods, this area was controlled by Khalil and Afridi tribesmen.  A traditional phrase showing the extent of one country spoke of it as stretching from this place to Kanyakumari. Hari Singh Nalwa defended the eastern end of this place at the Battle of Jamrud as the forces of Dost Mohammad Khan sought to recapture the city of (*) Peshawar. The final section of the Durand line to be drawn was that near this area. This pass crosses the Spin Ghar mountains linking Landi Kotal with the Peshawar Valley in the North-west of Pakistan. For 10 points, name this mountain pass often seen as the entry point to the Indian subcontinent.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Khyber Pass

tossups.question: Gladys Aylward teaches the children this song at the end of The Inn of the Sixth Happiness A distinctive word in this song refers to the nuchal ligament which connects a sheep’s neck to its head. The Flanders and Swann song “All Gall'' uses the tune of this song. This song became an unofficial theme tune to Columbo as he whistled it while working out mysteries. Barney the Dinosaur sang (*) “I Love You” to this song’s tune at the end of his show. As this counting song increases in number the title figure plays “knick-knack” on different body parts. tossups.answer_sanitized: “This Old Man”

tossups.question: This family ran a Montana management company named in honour of the film Scarface. Food taster Kamel Gegeo was clubbed to death by a member of this family at a party. Latif Yahia served as the alleged body-double for a member of this family who used his position as head of a national Olympic committee to commit unspeakable acts. A member of this family wrote the allegorical romance novel Zabibah and the King, in which the title woman is terrorized by a man who represents the (*) United States. Members of this family used the name al-Tikrit as they originated from the city of Tikrit. Uday and Qusay, members of this family were depicted as Aces in a US-issued deck of cards as they were considered likely to replace their father as leader of the Ba’ath Party. For 10 points, what was the surname of Iraq’s president Saddam.
tossups.question_sanitized: This family ran a Montana management company named in honour of the film Scarface. Food taster Kamel Gegeo was clubbed to death by a member of this family at a party. Latif Yahia served as the alleged body-double for a member of this family who used his position as head of a national Olympic committee to commit unspeakable acts. A member of this family wrote the allegorical romance novel Zabibah and the King, in which the title woman is terrorized by a man who represents the (*) United States. Members of this family used the name al-Tikrit as they originated from the city of Tikrit. Uday and Qusay, members of this family were depicted as Aces in a US-issued deck of cards as they were considered likely to replace their father as leader of the Ba’ath Party. For 10 points, what was the surname of Iraq’s president Saddam.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Hussein [accept Saddam Hussein, Uday Hussein, Qusay Hussein, or Barzan Hussein]

tossups.question: A theory by this scientist can be geometrically re-formulated using four-dimensional spacetime to create a theory named for this scientist and Élie Cartan (“ellie” kar-TAWN). This scientist lends his name to a 6-variable equation that combines Euler’s (“oiler’s”) two laws of motion for a rigid body. In systems named for this scientist, shear stress and shear rate are linearly correlated, meaning that viscosity is constant. This scientist posited that a body’s rate of (*) heat loss is proportional to the difference between its temperature and the surrounding temperature, known as his law of cooling. A constant roughly equal to “6.7 times 10 to the negative 11” is used in this scientist’s law of universal gravitation. For 10 points, name this scientist who stated that force equals mass times acceleration as one of his three laws of motion.
tossups.answer: Sir Isaac Newton [accept Newton-Cartan theory, Newton-Euler equations, Newtonian fluids, Newton’s law of cooling, or Newton’s laws of motion]

tossups.question: This golfer beat Corey Pavin in a 2010 play-off to win his first PGA tour title at the Travelers Championship. With Ben Crane, Rickie Fowler, and Hunter Mahan this man released the charity single “Oh Oh Oh” with the “Gold Boys”. This golfer has paired with Webb Simpson six times in the Ryder Cup but has never won. This golfer is a part owner of the Pensacola Blue Wahoos and owns the first General Lee used to film The Dukes of Hazzard. This player beat Louis (*) Oosthuizen in a major play-off by hitting a miraculous shot through the pine straw at Augusta National. For 10 points, name this Bagdad, Florida-born golfer who won the Masters in 2012 and 2014.
tossups.question_sanitized: This golfer beat Corey Pavin in a 2010 play-off to win his first PGA tour title at the Travelers Championship. With Ben Crane, Rickie Fowler, and Hunter Mahan this man released the charity single “Oh Oh Oh” with the “Gold Boys”. This golfer is a part owner of the Pensacola Blue Wahoos and owns the first General Lee used to film The Dukes of Hazzard. This player beat Louis (*) Oosthuizen in a major play-off by hitting a miraculous shot through the pine straw at Augusta National. For 10 points, name this Bagdad, Florida-born golfer who won the Masters in 2012 and 2014.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Bubba Watson

tossups.question: In an essay by John Darnielle, this composer inspires the singer to think of “U.G. Krishnamurti…Current 93…and endless smoke”. After a dialogue with Toru Takemitsu, this composer decided to translate a Basho haiku as “What mushroom? / What leaf?” With the violinist Paul Zukofsky, this man composed the Freeman Etudes. The St. Burchadi Church in Halberstadt is the site of this composer’s very long organ piece As Slow as Possible. Performances of a 1951 indeterminate composition by this composer are guided by the (*) I Ching. David Tudor premiered this composer’s piece Music of Changes. This composer of the Imaginary Landscapes series made early, and regular, use of the prepared piano. For 10 points, name this minimalist composer of 4’33”.

Performances of a 1951 indeterminate composition by this composer are guided by the (*) I Ching. David Tudor premiered this composer’s piece Music of Changes. This composer of the Imaginary Landscapes series made early, and regular, use of the prepared piano. For 10 points, name this minimalist composer of 4’33”.
tossups.answer_sanitized: John Cage [or John Milton Cage Jr.]

tossups.question: The wandering “dhooley bearer” Lutchman assists a colonial doctor with research on this disease in one novel. Murugan carries out historical research on this disease in that novel. A treatment for this disease is central to the novel The Calcutta Chromosome by Amitav Ghosh. The title character of Henry James’ book (*) Daisy Miller contracts this insect-born disease from the swamps around the Colosseum. In the plays of Shakespeare, this disease was often called “ague”, while a particularly deadly strain of this disease was often described as “Roman fever”. In Kipling’s novel Kim, for 10 points, quinine is used to treat what mosquito-born disease?

tossups.answer_sanitized: malaria [accept Roman fever before mentioned]

tossups.question: An object named for this commodity was “born on a Friday,” and sits sideways on its own throne. While attempting to enforce the Treaty of Fomena ("fo-MAY-na"), Frederick Hodgson made an ill-advised demand for an object made of this commodity, leading to a war declared by Queen Mother Yaa. “Fields” rich in this commodity included Bure ("BOO-ray"), which contained the city of (*) Niani ("nee-YAH-nee"), and Bambuk ("BOMB-book"), which was used by the Soninke ("so-NING-kay") empire. A stool made of this commodity symbolized the ruler of the Ashanti Empire. King Tushratta ("tush-ROT-ta") claimed that this commodity was more common than dirt in Egypt. The value of this commodity in Cairo dropped significantly for over a decade after Mansa Musa traded it for souvenirs during his hajj. For 10 points, name this precious metal that formerly named the region now called Ghana.

A stool made of this commodity symbolized the ruler of the Ashanti Empire. King Tushratta ("tush-ROT-ta") claimed that this commodity was more common than dirt in Egypt. The value of this commodity in Cairo dropped significantly for over a decade after Mansa Musa traded it for souvenirs during his hajj. For 10 points, name this precious metal that formerly named the region now called Ghana.
tossups.answer_sanitized: gold [accept the Golden Stool or the Gold Coast]

tossups.question: A Rachel Corbett book titled for a line by this author traces this author's ties to a man who fired this author for sending correspondence without permission. Georg Simmel sponsored this author's trips throughout Europe, including two ill-fated visits to Russia to see Tolstoy arranged by this author's mentor Lou Andreas-Salome. This personal assistant to Auguste Rodin described stone as glistening "like a wild beast's fur" in a sculpture-inspired poem. That poem by this author analogizes a pair of eyes to (*) "ripening fruit", and concludes "for here there is no place that does not see you: you must change your life." A collection by this poet begins with the question "Who, if I cried out, would hear me among the angelic orders?" and was named for the castle in Trieste where it was written. For 10 points, name this German-language poet of "Archaic Torso of Apollo" and The Duino Elegies.
tossups.answer: Rainier Maria Rilke [or René Karl Wilhelm Johann Josef Maria Rilke]

tossups.answer_sanitized: Rainier Maria Rilke [or René Karl Wilhelm Johann Josef Maria Rilke]

tossups.question: Different depictions of this deity depend on the words amphis echousi meaning “to carry around”. Calypso was sometimes considered to be the daughter of Pleione and this mythological figure. A pioneering book depicted this figure as a King of Mauretania in its frontispiece, leading books in this genre to bear his name. This deity was the father of the Pleiades and the Hyades. This deity was turned to (*) stone by Medusa’s head when he refused to host Perseus, fearing a son of Zeus. Heracles took the place of this deity when he was attempting to recover the apples of the Hesperides. For 10 points, name this Titan who was condemned to hold the world on his shoulders.

This deity was turned to (*) stone by Medusa’s head when he refused to host Perseus, fearing a son of Zeus. Heracles took the place of this deity when he was attempting to recover the apples of the Hesperides. For 10 points, name this Titan who was condemned to hold the world on his shoulders.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Atlas

tossups.question: Decimus Brutus attached hooks to long poles to cripple enemy sails during a naval battle in this conflict. Lucterius and Drapes ("DRA-pees") snuck past a siege during this conflict to forage but when discovered were forced to split up and try to retreat to Uxellodunum. Quintus Sabinus and Lucius Cotta were killed after being tricked by the Eburones during this war. Aulus Hirtius wrote the final eight books of a history of this conflict. Ariovistus led forces to defeat the (*) Aedui in this war but was forced to retreat after being defeated at the Battle of the Vosges. The siege of Alesia took place during this war, a history of which begins by describing how all of the title province was divided into three parts. For 10 points, Julius Caesar fought what series of wars to seize control of modern France?
tossups.question_sanitized: Decimus Brutus attached hooks to long poles to cripple enemy sails during a naval battle in this conflict. Lucterius and Drapes ("DRA-pees") snuck past a siege during this conflict to forage but when discovered were forced to split up and try to retreat to Uxellodunum. Quintus Sabinus and Lucius Cotta were killed after being tricked by the Eburones during this war. Aulus Hirtius wrote the final eight books of a history of this conflict. Ariovistus led forces to defeat the (*) Aedui in this war but was forced to retreat after being defeated at the Battle of the Vosges. The siege of Alesia took place during this war, a history of which begins by describing how all of the title province was divided into three parts. For 10 points, Julius Caesar fought what series of wars to seize control of modern France?
tossups.answer_sanitized: Gallic Wars [accept Bellum Gallicum; accept Commentarii de Bello Gallico]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Carolyn Napoli’s work with Jorgensen on the cosuppression of this trait predated the discovery of RNA interference. The Ac/Ds (“A-C-D-S”) element affects this trait and earned Barbara McClintock the 1983 Nobel for discovering transposons (“trans-pose-ons”). A cylindrical capsid is found in a virus named for its effect on this trait and was the first ever discovered. While rediscovering Mendel’s work Carl Correns studied this trait of the four o’clock in the prototypical example of incomplete dominance, where this trait ends up the average of the parents. A 17th-century (*) Dutch speculative bubble centered on a breaking virus’s ability to radically change this trait by redistributing anthocyanin (“antho-cyan-in”). For 10 points, name this trait affected by the tobacco mosaic virus, which naturally varies in tulips from yellow and red to white.
tossups.answer: coloration [or coloring; accept flower, petal, bulb, kernel, stalk, or leaf coloration or pigmentation; prompt on the tobacco mosaic virus or mosaicism before mentioned]
tossups.question_sanitized: Description acceptable. Carolyn Napoli’s work with Jorgensen on the cosuppression of this trait predated the discovery of RNA interference. The Ac/Ds (“A-C-D-S”) element affects this trait and earned Barbara McClintock the 1983 Nobel for discovering transposons (“trans-pose-ons”). A cylindrical capsid is found in a virus named for its effect on this trait and was the first ever discovered. While rediscovering Mendel’s work Carl Correns studied this trait of the four o’clock in the prototypical example of incomplete dominance, where this trait ends up the average of the parents. A 17th-century (*) Dutch speculative bubble centered on a breaking virus’s ability to radically change this trait by redistributing anthocyanin (“antho-cyan-in”). For 10 points, name this trait affected by the tobacco mosaic virus, which naturally varies in tulips from yellow and red to white.
tossups.answer_sanitized: coloration [or coloring; accept flower, petal, bulb, kernel, stalk, or leaf coloration or pigmentation; prompt on the tobacco mosaic virus or mosaicism before mentioned]

parts: Give this suffix found in a class of antihelmintic (“anti-hel-MIN-tick”) drugs that help treat river blindness, lymphatic filariasis (“fil-a-RYE-a-sis”), and scabies.

Though often called horse dewormer paste, ivermectin is also a pill that treats infections with these parasites. Only the “body” species of these insects spread disease, but the “head” and “pubic” varieties are still major pests.

Avermectins target the worms that carry numerous diseases with this designation, which is defined as “not HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, or malaria”. Despite relatively cheap medications, the prevalence of diseases with this designation make the overall cost to treat them higher than many world governments can manage.

parts: Name this Christian knight of Beaucaire who falls in love with the Saracen captive Nicolette in a medieval French romance.
A chantefable combines prose and this kind of writing. Imagist and Beat poets made heavy use of the "free" form of this type of writing, which has neither rhyme nor meter.

In contrast to free verse, this type of poem has a strict rhyme scheme consisting of an octave rhyming ABBAABBA and a sestina rhyming CDECDE. The two parts of this type of poem are separated by a volta, or turn.

porphyrins [or porphyrin rings; prompt on porphyria]
parts: Name this very symmetric molecule. The sixty atoms in this molecule are arranged into an icosahedral shell identical to a soccer ball.

Functionalized (“function-al-ized”) examples of these molecules bound to zinc have recently taken the double-slit crown from buckyballs. These annular compounds are able to coordinate metals with their pyrrole (“PIR-roll”) subunits and defects in their synthesis can produce discolored urine.
The color of porphyrins stems from their large conjugated systems of these bonds, which are formed from one sigma and one pi bond. The presence of these bonds defines alkenes (“al-KEENs”).

parts: Name this set of values sometimes known as risk sensitivities used to measure the sensitivity of an option’s price to underlying parameters.

parts: Identify this actor. This actor played Chester Desmond, who begins work on the case that Dale Cooper picks up in Twin Peaks.

Isaak is likely best-known for what 1989 single, which became a hit after it was featured by David Lynch in the film Wild at Heart? This song begins with Isaak singing “The world was on fire, and no on could save me but you”.
Chris Isaak, Brooke Shields, and Julia Roberts are among the celebrities to make cameos in “The One After the Superbowl”, a 1996 episode of this sitcom.
